title: As Omicron Variant Circles the Globe, African Nations Face Blame and Bans
content: With countries trying to close their doors to the new coronavirus variant, southern African officials note that the West’s hoarding of vaccines helped create their struggle in the first place.

more_info.byline: By Benjamin Mueller and Declan Walsh

title: A Wine Rack on Rails? U.K. Businesses Seek Solutions to Shortages.
content: Two months after concerns about gas and food stocks caused ripples of anxiety, Britain continues to face problems in its supply chain. Distributors and retailers are looking for creative fixes.

more_info.byline: By Stephen Castle and Jenny Gross

title: Israel and Iran Broaden Cyberwar to Attack Civilian Targets
content: Iranians couldn’t buy gas. Israelis found their intimate dating details posted online. The Iran-Israel shadow war is now hitting ordinary citizens.

more_info.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman

title: What’s at Stake in the Honduran Presidential Election?
content: Hondurans head to the polls on Sunday, but widespread political violence during the campaign and questionable results from 2017 are looming large.

title: ‘You’re Not Helpless’: For London Women, Learning to Fight Builds Confidence
content: After a year marked by isolation, loneliness and violence in the city, many self-defense and martial arts gyms say they are seeing more interest from women.

title: Iran Forcefully Clamps Down on Protests Against Growing Water Shortages
content: The crackdown came after the protests spilled over to at least one other city and a major protest on Friday loomed. Weather experts say 97 percent of the country is dealing with water scarcity issues.

title: They Twice Gave Up Everything to Flee Iraq. They Keep Getting Sent Back.
content: Bria Ali and her family have twice tried to make it to Germany, desperate for a better life. They are now back home with thousands of others who made it to Europe in recent months only to be deported.

title: A Tale of Culinary Reconciliation, Beside the Eiffel Tower
content: Two decades ago, Spain was the new France, leading gastronomic innovation. Now two iconic chefs have joined forces in Paris.

title: A Couple’s Dream of Reuniting in England Is Dashed in a Channel Disaster
content: A young Kurdish woman, Maryam Nuri, died with 26 others after making a desperate attempt to join her fiancé by crossing the English Channel from France on an inflatable boat.

des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

title: Brazil’s President Lula Is Staging a Comeback. Can He Bring the Country Along?
content: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the former president, has beat back a flurry of corruption cases and climbed to the front of next year’s presidential race.

title: 3 Bodies Found Amid Violence in Solomon Islands
content: The police were trying to determine if the charred remains found in the capital’s Chinatown district were linked to the protests, in which demonstrators set fire to buildings.

title: Afghan Economy Nears Collapse as Pressure Builds to Ease U.S. Sanctions
content: Afghanistan’s economy has crashed since the Taliban seized power, plunging the country into one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises.

title: France-U.K. Acrimony Impedes Progress on Channel Crossings
content: Rather than working together to curb hazardous sea crossings, leaders of the two countries almost immediately fell into a familiar pattern of squabbling.

title: ‘Afghan Girl’ From 1985 National Geographic Cover Takes Refuge in Italy
content: Sharbat Gula, whose haunting portrait was featured by the magazine more than three decades ago, was evacuated to Rome after the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan.

title: In a Nonbinary Pronoun, France Sees a U.S. Attack on the Republic
content: When a French dictionary included the gender-nonspecific “iel” for the first time, a virulent reaction erupted over “wokisme” exported from American universities.

more_info.byline: By Roger Cohen and Léontine Gallois
des_facet: Le Petit Robert de la Langue Francaise (Book)

title: As concerts return to South Korea, fans are told not to sing along.
content: South Koreans including K-pop fans will not be able to shout, chant or sing at performances with 500 or more attendees, according to government rules.

title: Britain announces a third case of the Omicron variant as the health secretary defends decision on restrictions.
content: The government stopped short of urging people to work from home or extending vaccine passports in England after cases of the Omicron variant were detected.

title: A soccer game in Portugal is abandoned after Covid reduces one team to 9 players.
content: Players from the Belenenses team criticized sporting officials for demanding the match go on, saying soccer had “lost its heart.”

title: The W.H.O. skips forward two Greek letters, avoiding a Xi variant.
content: Under the World Health Organization’s system, the Omicron variant might have been called Nu or Xi, but only at the risk of ambiguity or diplomatic awkwardness.

title: Laszlo Z. Bito, Scientist, Novelist and Philanthropist, Dies at 87
content: He fled communist rule in Hungary, discovered a treatment for glaucoma in the U.S., then became an author and a voice against authoritarianism in his homeland.

title: How did Omicron get its name?
The U.K. confirms two cases of the Omicron coronavirus variant.
content: The prime minister reimposed a mask mandate, saying ‘there are many things we just cannot know.’

more_info.byline: By Aina J. Khan and Isabella Grullón Paz

title: Chaos for passengers in Amsterdam is one sign of a scattershot response to the variant.
content: Dutch health authorities say it’s likely the Omicron variant will be detected among 61 infected travelers from South Africa.

more_info.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Claire Moses

title: How Omicron, the New Covid-19 Variant, Got Its Name
content: The World Health Organization began naming the variants after Greek letters to avoid public confusion and stigma.

title: Germany confirms cases of the variant in a married couple.
content: A couple returning from South Africa are Germany’s first confirmed Omicron cases. Italy confirmed a case in a traveler returning from Mozambique.

more_info.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Christopher F. Schuetze

title: More countries restrict travel from southern Africa.
content: Australia, Canada and Thailand are among the latest countries to restrict travelers from the region over concerns about the Omicron variant.

more_info.byline: By Mike Ives, John Yoon, Yan Zhuang and Aina J. Khan

title: The Netherlands finds 61 Covid cases in air arrivals from South Africa, and is checking for the variant.
content: The passengers were in the air when the Netherlands announced travel restrictions on flights from southern Africa.

title: Giving Thanks in Australia
content: It’s an odd affair outside America, but maybe the holiday will inspire more of us to pause and appreciate the gifts we’ve been given.

title: In the Midst of the Mud and Destruction, British Columbians Come Together
content: A tour of the flood-ravaged parts of the province finds communities supporting each other following disaster.

title: New ‘Variant of Concern’ Fuels Global Fear of Another Virus Surge
content: Scientists do not yet know how dangerous the new Omicron variant is, but its many mutations set off alarms, lowering hopes of putting the pandemic in the past.

more_info.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Jason Horowitz

title: Seeking Backers for New Fund, Jared Kushner Turns to Middle East
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law is trying to raise capital for his investment firm and is turning to a region that he dealt with extensively while in the White House.

more_info.byline: By Kate Kelly, David D. Kirkpatrick and Alan Rappeport

title: New Virus Variant Stokes Concern but Vaccines Still Likely to Work
content: The Omicron variant carries worrisome mutations that may let it evade antibodies, scientists said. But it will take more research to know how it fares against vaccinated people.

title: After detecting the Omicron variant, South Africa feels ‘punished’ by global travel bans.
content: Hours after South African scientists announced the existence of a troublesome new variant, Britain banned travelers from southern Africa. The United States and other nations quickly followed suit.

title: A Mine Disaster in Russia Highlights Safety Shortfalls in Rush to Dig Coal
content: At least 46 miners were killed in an explosion at a Siberian mine. The director of the mine has been taken into police custody, along with five other administrators.

title: United States will bar travelers from 8 countries in southern Africa.
content: Starting Monday, travelers from South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique and Malawi will be barred unless they are citizens or permanent residents.

more_info.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

title: Merck says its antiviral pill is less effective than initially reported.
content: The drug, molnupiravir, reduced the risk of hospitalization and death in high-risk Covid patients by 30 percent. An earlier analysis had found a 50 percent reduction.

title: Protesters in Martinique fire at police officers and journalists.
content: Protests against the French island’s coronavirus protocols, requiring a health pass to enter most public venues, have been exacerbated by frustrations and anger over economic inequality with the mainland.

title: Jakucho Setouchi, 99, Dies; Buddhist Priest Wrote of Sex and Love
content: Her more than 400 novels often drew on her own romantic affairs, and her translation of an 11th-century romantic Japanese classic sold millions of copies.

more_info.byline: By Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
